node.text: From saving the planet to understanding ourselves, The Big Questions - IFLScience's new podcast series - will see experts discuss the major topics of our times. Coming soon to your favourite apps!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by IFLScience on August 23, 2021. May be a closeup of nature.

node.text:
Say hello to the Javan tree frog (Rhacophorus margaritifer), a species of frog from the Rhacophoridae family who is, unsurprisingly, native to Java in Indonesia. Locally it’s known as katak-parasut jawa.

The frog comes in a variety of colors, from a smorgasbord of greens to burnt oranges with small black spots, and striking eyes that can be yellow or grey with a horizontal black pupil. Their groovy get-up means they can blend into their jungle habitat, a handy skill when snakes, spiders and bats are out to get you.

Image credit: Kurit afshen / Shutterstock.com

Martin Kaae Kristiansen from Denmark captured this outstanding footage showing individual tardigrade muscles glowing under polarized light. It featured as one of the honorable mentions for the Nikon Small World in Motion competition, and we couldn’t resist featuring it as our #MicrobeMonday today. 

Now celebrating its 11th year, Nikon Small World in Motion is the video component of the long-standing Nikon Small World still-photography competition. The competition recognizes proficiency and excellence of photography and video taken under the microscope.

Video credit: Martin Kaae Kristiansen @my.microscopic.world
Courtesy of @nikoninstruments

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by IFLScience on August 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'IFLS Study Reveals What Happens When Drugs Are Legalized'.

node.text:
Hit this image via the link in our bio to read the full story 📖
​
​Drug law reform has become a major topic of debate in recent years, with a growing number of states and nations choosing to decriminalize or even legalize certain substances following decades of prohibition. The pace of change has caused a split in opinions, with some praising governments for being bold while others have expressed concern at the potential harms that could result from these liberal policies. Yet as the hard data begins to trickle in, scientists are now gaining a more concrete understanding of how policy changes affect drug use and drug markets.

A recent study in the journal Addiction, for example, reveals how the legalization of recreational cannabis has altered the nature of various illegal drug markets in the US. So far, 15 states plus the District of Columbia have implemented recreational cannabis laws (RCLs), resulting in massive changes in the amount and potency of other illicit drugs circulating on the streets.
​

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by IFLScience on August 22, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text.

node.text:
The greenbottle blue tarantula (Chromatopelma cyaneopubescens) is known for its vivid metallic blue legs and blue-green carapace. Native to the desert areas of northern Venezuela, they live in webbed burrows under local foliage like bushes and tree roots.
​
They are impressive webbers, crafting their web to protect themselves from the harsh desert climate and as well as working as a trap for insects like crickets, roaches, and even worms.
​
​Image credit: Cathy Keifer / Shutterstock

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by IFLScience on August 22, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
The platypus (Ornithorhynchus anatinus) is a very unusual creature. Measuring around 51cm in length and weighing roughly 1 kg, it’s a mash up between a duck (webbed feet), a beaver (tail) and an otter (body and fur) that’s found paddling around in eastern Australia including Tasmania. 

Platypuses mainly hunt underwater, snuffling in the sediment for insects, larvae and shellfish. They store their catch in cheek pouches and bring it to the surface so they can crush it all up for dinner. 

As innocent as they seem, the males actually pack a venomous spur on the back of their heel which can deliver a nasty shot of toxins to any enemies that get too close. While we can relate to the allure of a beaver-cum-duck-cum-otter, best not pet these perplexing, aquatic noodles.

Image credit: Mari May / worldswildlifewonders / Shutterstock.com

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by IFLScience on August 21, 2021. May be an image of big cat and nature.

node.text:
Snow leopards (Panthera uncia), nicknamed the “ounce”, are native to the mountain ranges of Central and South Asia. These impressive cats can grow to over 200cm in length including their tails, and weigh from 27 to 54 kg.

Naturally built to tolerate the harsh conditions of mountain life, snow leopards have light-colored fur with grey patches that helps them blend into their surroundings as well as keeping them warm. Their famously floofy feet are basically natural snowshoes. 

When conditions are cold, calories are key and to ensure their survival they’ve adapted to take down animals three times their weight. However, hungry predators can’t always be choosers and they’re not above scooping up smaller prey such as hares, marmots and game birds.

Despite being efficient hunters, the snow leopard population is in a dramatic decline with over 20% of their population having been lost over the last two decades due to poaching and habitat destruction. 

Image credit: Vladimir Turhenich / Vladislav T. Jirousek / Shutterstock.com

node.text:
This is 'The Humanity Globe' - an awesome visualization showing the world according to population density. Its creator, Tyler Morgan-Wall, used data from the Gridded Population of the World collection (GPWv4) which models human population based on census reports, and the United Nation's World Population Prospects report. 
​
​Video credit: Tyler Morgan-Wall
​Click this video in the link in our bio to check out more of Tyler's awesome visualizations on his twitter page @tylermorganwall.

node.text:
Meet Beuno the adorable baby tamandua, ZSL London Zoo’s latest newborn.

Tamanduas are a type of anteater, part of the suborder Vermilingua, meaning “worm tongue”. Babies weigh just 380 grams, but adults can grow up to 8 kg. Bueno is currently about 25 cm long but southern tamanduas can reach a length of 88 cm with their tails adding another 59 cm.

Tamaduas don’t have teeth but their tongues can grow up to 40 cm in length - perfect for sucking up yummy snacks like ants and termites.  Juvenile tamanduas spend the first three months holding on to their mother’s backs and sliding down to feed before pulling themselves back up into mom’s fur. Aw!
​
Footage courtesy of: @zsllondonzoo
